Let $A B=h$ metres. From the right $	riangle O A B$, we have $$  egin{aligned}  rac{A B}{O A} & =	an 60^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \ \Rightarrow  rac{h}{25} & =\sqrt{3} \end{aligned} $$ $\Rightarrow h=25 	imes \sqrt{3}=25 	imes 1.732=43.3$. questions.answer: Let $A B$ be the tower and let $A C$ and $A D$ be its shadows when the angles of elevation of the sun are $60^{\circ}$ and $45^{\circ}$ respectively. $$  egin{aligned} 	herefore \quad \angle A C B & =60^{\circ}, \angle A D B=45^{\circ}, \ \angle D A B & =90^{\circ} 	ext { and } C D=10 \mathrm{~m} . \end{aligned} $$ Let $A B=h$ metres and $A C=x$ metres. From right $	riangle C A B$, we get  egin{align*} &  rac{A C}{A B}=\cot 60^{\circ}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \ \Rightarrow &  rac{x}{h}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow x= rac{h}{\sqrt{3}} . 	ag{i} \end{align*} From right $	riangle D A B$, we get  egin{align*} &  rac{A D}{A B}=\cot 45^{\circ}=1 \Rightarrow  rac{x+10}{h}=1 \ \Rightarrow & x+10=h \Rightarrow x=h-10 . 	ag{ii} \end{align*} Equating the values of $x$ from (i) and (ii), we get $$  egin{aligned}  rac{h}{\sqrt{3}}=h-10 & \Rightarrow h=\sqrt{3} h-10 \sqrt{3} \Rightarrow(\sqrt{3}-1) h=10 \sqrt{3} \ \Rightarrow h= rac{10 \sqrt{3}}{(\sqrt{3}-1)} & =\left\{ rac{10 \sqrt{3}}{(\sqrt{3}-1)} 	imes  rac{(\sqrt{3}+1)}{(\sqrt{3}+1)}ight\} \ & =5 \sqrt{3}(\sqrt{3}+1)=15+5 \sqrt{3} \end{aligned} $$ $$ \Rightarrow \quad h=(5+5 	imes 1.732)=(15+8.66)=23.66 . $$ Hence, the height of the tower is $23.66 \mathrm{~m}$. questions.answer: Let $P Q$ be the tower and let $P A$ and $P B$ be its shadows when the altitudes of the sun are $45^{\circ}$ and $30^{\circ}$ respectively. Then, $$ \angle P A Q=45^{\circ}, \angle P B Q=30^{\circ}, \angle B P Q=90^{\circ}, P Q=50 \mathrm{~m} . $$ Let $A B=x$ metres. From right $	riangle A P Q$, we have $$  egin{aligned} &  rac{A P}{P Q}=\cot 45^{\circ}=1 \ \Rightarrow &  rac{A P}{50 \mathrm{~m}}=1 \Rightarrow A P=50 \mathrm{~m} . \end{aligned} $$ From right $	riangle B P Q$, we have $$  egin{aligned} &  rac{B P}{P Q}=\cot 30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow  rac{x+50}{50}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow x=50(\sqrt{3}-1) . \ \Rightarrow & x=50(1.732-1)=(50 	imes 0.732)=36.6 \end{aligned} $$ Hence, $x=36.6$.

questions.answer: Let $A B$ be the tower and let $A C$ and $A D$ be the lengths of its shadows when $\angle A C B=60^{\circ}$ and $\angle A D B=30^{\circ}$. Let $A B=h$ metres, and $A C=x$ metres. From right $	riangle C A B$, we have  egin{align*} &  rac{A C}{A B}=\cot 60^{\circ}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow  rac{x}{h}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \ \Rightarrow \quad & x=\left(h 	imes  rac{1}{\sqrt{3}}ight)= rac{h}{\sqrt{3}} . 	ag{i} \end{align*} From right $	riangle D A B$, we have  egin{align*} &  rac{A D}{A B}=\cot 30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow  rac{x+30}{h}=\sqrt{3} \ \Rightarrow \quad & x=(\sqrt{3} h-30) . 	ag{ii} \end{align*} Equating the values of $x$ from (i) and (ii), we get $$  egin{aligned} &  rac{h}{\sqrt{3}}=(\sqrt{3} h-30) \Rightarrow h=3 h-30 \sqrt{3} \ \Rightarrow & 2 h=30 \sqrt{3} \Rightarrow h=15 \sqrt{3}=(15 	imes 1.732)=25.98 . \end{aligned} $$ Hence, the height of the tower is $25.98 \mathrm{~m}$.

Let $A B=h$ metres and $O A=x$ metres. From right $	riangle O A B$, we have  egin{align*}  rac{O A}{A B}=\cot 30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} & \Rightarrow  rac{x}{h}=\sqrt{3} \ & \Rightarrow x=h \sqrt{3} . 	ag{i} \end{align*} From right $	riangle O A C$, we have  egin{align*} &  rac{O A}{A C}=\cot 60^{\circ}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \ \Rightarrow &  rac{x}{h+5}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow x= rac{h+5}{\sqrt{3}} . 	ag{ii} \end{align*} Equating the values of $x$ from (i) and (ii), we get $$ h \sqrt{3}= rac{h+5}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow 3 h=h+5 \Rightarrow 2 h=5 \Rightarrow h=2.5 $$ Hence, the height of the tower is 2.5 metres.

questions.question: Two pillars of equal heights stand on either side of a road which is $100 \mathrm{~m}$ wide. At a point on the road between the pillars, the angles of elevation of the tops of the pillars are $60^{\circ}$ and $30^{\circ}$. Find the height of each pillar and position of the point on the road. [Take $\sqrt{3}=1.732$.]
questions.answer: Let $A B$ and $C D$ be two pillars, each of height $h$ metres and let $A C$ be the road such that $A C=100 \mathrm{~m}$. Let $O$ be the point of observation on $A C$. Let $O A=x$ metres and $O C=(100-x) \mathrm{m}$. Also, $\angle A O B=60^{\circ}$ and $\angle C O D=30^{\circ}$. $A B \perp A C$ and $C D \perp A C$. From right $	riangle O A B$, we have $$  egin{aligned} &  rac{A B}{O A}=	an 60^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \ \Rightarrow &  rac{h}{x}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow h=\sqrt{3} x . \end{aligned} $$ From right $	riangle O C D$, we have  egin{align*} &  rac{C D}{O C}=	an 30^{\circ}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \ \Rightarrow &  rac{h}{(100-x)}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow h= rac{(100-x)}{\sqrt{3}} . 	ag{ii} \end{align*} Equating the values of $h$ from (i) and (ii), we get $$ \sqrt{3} x= rac{(100-x)}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow 3 x=(100-x) \Rightarrow 4 x=100 \Rightarrow x=25 $$ Putting $x=25 \mathrm{~m}$ in (i), we get $$ h=(25 	imes \sqrt{3})=(25 	imes 1.732)=43.3 $$ Hence, the height of each pillar is $43.3 \mathrm{~m}$ and the point of observation is $25 \mathrm{~m}$ away from the first pillar.

Then, $$ \angle C O A=60^{\circ}, \angle D O B=30^{\circ} $$ and $A C=B D=1500 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{~m}$. From right $	riangle O C A$, we have $$  rac{O C}{A C}=\cot 60^{\circ}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} $$ $$ \Rightarrow  rac{O C}{1500 \sqrt{3}}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow O C=1500 \mathrm{~m} . $$ From right $	riangle O D B$, we have $$  egin{aligned} &  rac{O D}{B D}=\cot 30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow  rac{O D}{1500 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{~m}}=\sqrt{3} \ \Rightarrow \quad & O D=(1500 	imes 3) \mathrm{m}=4500 \mathrm{~m} . \ 	herefore \quad & C D=(O D-O C)=(4500-1500) \mathrm{m}=3000 \mathrm{~m} . \end{aligned} $$ Thus, the aeroplane covers $300 \mathrm{~m}$ in 15 seconds. $	herefore \quad$ speed of the aeroplane $=\left( rac{3000}{15} 	imes  rac{60 	imes 60}{1000}ight) \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr}$ $$ =720 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr} 	ext {. } $$ Hence, the speed of the aeroplane is $720 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hr}$.

questions.question: A man on a cliff observes a boat at an angle of depression of $30^{\circ}$ which is approaching the shore to the point immediately beneath the observer with a uniform speed. Six minutes later, the angle of depression of the boat is found to be $60^{\circ}$. Find the total time taken by the boat to reach the shore.
questions.answer: Let $A B$ be the cliff with the man at $B$. Let $C$ and $D$ be the two positions of the boat approaching the shore at $A$. Then, $$ \angle A C B=30^{\circ} 	ext { and } \angle A D B=60^{\circ} 	ext {. } $$ Let $A B=h$ metres, $C D=x$ metres From right $	riangle D A B$, we have  egin{equation*}  rac{A D}{A B}=\cot 60^{\circ}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow  rac{y}{h}= rac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow y= rac{h}{\sqrt{3}} . 	ag{i} \end{equation*} From right $	riangle C A B$, we have  egin{equation*}  rac{A C}{A B}=\cot 30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow  rac{x+y}{h}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow x+y=h \sqrt{3} 	ext {. } 	ag{ii} \end{equation*} On subtracting (i) from (ii), we get  egin{equation*} x=\left(h \sqrt{3}- rac{h}{\sqrt{3}}ight) \Rightarrow x= rac{2 h}{\sqrt{3}} . 	ag{iii} \end{equation*} From (iii) and (i), we get $$ x: y= rac{2 h}{\sqrt{3}}:  rac{h}{\sqrt{3}}=2: 1 $$ Let the time taken to cover $y$ units be $t$ minutes. Then, ratio of distances $=$ ratio of times taken to cover them. So, $2: 1=6: t \Rightarrow  rac{2}{1}= rac{6}{t} \Rightarrow 2 t=6 \Rightarrow t=3$. Thus, the boat takes 3 minutes to cover the distance $D A$. Hence, the total time taken by the boat to reach the shore is $(6+3)$ minutes $=9$ minutes.

From right $	riangle B A C$, we have  egin{equation*}  rac{A C}{A B}=\cot 30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow  rac{x}{h}=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow x=h \sqrt{3} 	ag{ii} \end{equation*} Equating the values of $x$ from (i) and (ii), we get $$  egin{aligned} & 100-h=h \sqrt{3} \Rightarrow h(\sqrt{3}+1)=100 \ \Rightarrow & h=\left\{ rac{100}{(\sqrt{3}+1)} 	imes  rac{(\sqrt{3}-1)}{(\sqrt{3}-1)}ight\}=50(\sqrt{3}-1) \ \Rightarrow & h=50(1.732-1)=(50 	imes 0.732)=36.6 . \end{aligned} $$ Hence, the height of the lighthouse is $36.6 \mathrm{~m}$.

Let $C$ be the position of the cloud and let $D$ be its reflection in the lake. Draw $P Q \perp C D$. Then, $$  egin{aligned} & 2 \pi R=18 \Rightarrow \pi R=9 . \ & 2 \pi r=6 \Rightarrow \pi r=3 . \end{aligned} $$ Also, $l=4 \mathrm{~cm}$ (given). Curved surface area of the frustum $$  egin{aligned} & =\pi l(R+r) 	ext { sq units } \ & =l 	imes(\pi R+\pi r)=4 	imes(9+3) \mathrm{cm}^{2}=48 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \end{aligned} $$

Also, $	riangle O P D \sim 	riangle O Q B$. $$ 	herefore \quad  rac{O P}{O Q}= rac{P D}{Q B} \Rightarrow  rac{(h / 2)}{h}= rac{P D}{10} \Rightarrow P D=5 \mathrm{~cm} . $$ The plane $C D$ divides the cone into two parts, namely (i) a smaller cone of radius $=5 \mathrm{~cm}$ and height $(h / 2) \mathrm{cm}$, (ii) frustum of a cone in which $$ R=10 \mathrm{~cm}, r=5 \mathrm{~cm} 	ext { and height }=\left( rac{h}{2}ight) \mathrm{cm} . $$ Volume of the smaller cone $$ =\left( rac{1}{3} 	imes \pi 	imes 5 	imes 5 	imes  rac{h}{2}ight) \mathrm{cm}^{3}=\left( rac{25 \pi h}{6}ight) \mathrm{cm}^{3} . $$ Volume of the frustum of the cone $$ = rac{1}{3} \pi 	imes  rac{h}{2} \cdot\left[(10)^{2}+(5)^{2}+10 	imes 5ight] \mathrm{cm}^{3}=\left( rac{175 \pi h}{6}ight) \mathrm{cm}^{3} . $$ Ratio of the required volumes $= rac{25 \pi h}{6}:  rac{175 \pi h}{6}=25: 175=1: 7$.

questions.question: The height of a cone is $30 \mathrm{~cm}$. A small cone is cut off at the top by a plane parallel to the base. If its volume be $1 / 27$ of the volume of the given cone, at what height above the base is the section made?
questions.answer: Height of the given cone $=30 \mathrm{~cm}$. Let the radius of its base be $R \mathrm{~cm}$. Volume of the given cone $=\left( rac{1}{3} \pi R^{2} 	imes 30ight) \mathrm{cm}^{3}=\left(10 \pi R^{2}ight) \mathrm{cm}^{3}$. Let the radius and height of the smaller cone be $r \mathrm{~cm}$ and $h \mathrm{~cm}$ respectively. Then, volume of the smaller cone $=\left( rac{1}{3} \pi r^{2} hight) \mathrm{cm}^{3}$. $	herefore \quad  rac{1}{3} \pi r^{2} h= rac{1}{27} \cdot\left(10 \pi R^{2}ight) \quad$ [given] $\Rightarrow\left( rac{R}{r}ight)^{2}= rac{9 h}{10}$. Now, $	riangle O A B \sim 	riangle O C D$. $	herefore \quad  rac{A B}{C D}= rac{O A}{O C} \Rightarrow  rac{R}{r}= rac{30}{h}$. From (i) and (ii), we get $$  egin{aligned} & \left( rac{30}{h}ight)^{2}= rac{9 h}{10} \Rightarrow  rac{30 	imes 30}{h 	imes h}= rac{9 h}{10} \ \Rightarrow & h^{3}= rac{30 	imes 30 	imes 10}{9}=1000 \Rightarrow h^{3}=(10)^{3} \Rightarrow h=10 . \end{aligned} $$ $	herefore$ height of the smaller cone $=10 \mathrm{~cm}$. Height of the section from the base $=(30-10) \mathrm{cm}=20 \mathrm{~cm}$.

questions.question: A hollow cone is cut by a plane parallel to the base and the upper portion is removed. If the curved surface of the remainder is $8 / 9$ of the curved surface of the whole cone, find the ratio of the line segments into which the altitude of the cone is divided by the plane.
questions.answer: Let $O A B$ be the given hollow cone cut by the plane $C D$ parallel to base $A B$ and let cone $O C D$ be removed. Then, the remainder is the frustum $C A B D$ of the given cone. Let $O E=h$ units, $O F=H$ units, $O D=l$ units, $O B=L$ units, $E D=r$ units, $F B=R$ units. In $	riangle O E D$ and $	riangle O F B$, we have $\angle E O D=\angle F O B$ (common), $\angle O E D=\angle O F B=90^{\circ}$. $	herefore \quad 	riangle O E D \sim 	riangle O F B$ $\Rightarrow  rac{O E}{O F}= rac{O D}{O B}= rac{E D}{F B} \Rightarrow  rac{h}{H}= rac{l}{L}= rac{r}{R} \cdot \ldots$ (i) [by Thales' theorem] Now, (curved surface area of the frustum $C A B D$ ) $= rac{8}{9}($ curved surface area of the cone $O A B)$ $\Rightarrow$ (curved surface area of the cone $O C D$ ) $=($ curved surface of the cone $O A B)$  egin{itemize} \item (curved surface of the frustum $C A B D$ ) \end{itemize} $=($ curved surface of the cone $O A B)$ $- rac{8}{9}$ (curved surface of the cone $O A B$ ) $= rac{1}{9}($ curved surface of the cone $O A B)$ $\Rightarrow \pi r l= rac{1}{9} \pi R L$ $\Rightarrow\left( rac{r}{R}ight)\left( rac{l}{L}ight)= rac{1}{9} \Rightarrow\left( rac{h}{H} 	imes  rac{h}{H}ight)= rac{1}{9} \Rightarrow  rac{h}{H}= rac{1}{3} \quad[$ using (i) $]$ $\Rightarrow H=3 h$. Now, $E F=(O F-O E)=(H-h)=(3 h-h)=2 h$. $	herefore \quad  rac{O E}{E F}= rac{h}{2 h}= rac{1}{2}$. Hence, $O E: E F=1: 2$.

Also, $E F=10 \mathrm{~cm}$. Thus, $A B C D$ is the frustum of a cone in which $$ R= rac{20}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{~cm}, r= rac{10}{\sqrt{3}} \mathrm{~cm} 	ext { and } h=10 \mathrm{~cm} 	ext {. } $$ Volume of this frustum $= rac{1}{3} \pi h\left(R^{2}+r^{2}+R right)$ $$  egin{aligned} & = rac{1}{3} 	imes \pi 	imes 10\left\{ rac{400}{3}+ rac{100}{3}+ rac{200}{3}ight\} \mathrm{cm}^{3} \ & =\left( rac{\pi 	imes 10}{3} 	imes  rac{700}{3}ight) \mathrm{cm}^{3}=\left( rac{7000 \pi}{9}ight) \mathrm{cm}^{3} . \end{aligned} $$ Let the length of the wire be $l$.
